issue.title: Multi-shot routines should be able to ask for a sub-set of the dataframe

content.raw:
Sounds good, will do. It's a shame sending dataframes to subprocesses actually takes noticeable amounts of time, but there isn't really any aternative unless we swap out the dataframe for something less flexible.

Could also be a setting in lyse itself rather than the scripts, so you can change it for multiple scripts at once. Do multishot analysis on: shots from today/shots from last n sequences.

What do you think, better?
content.html:
Sounds good, will do. It's a shame sending dataframes to subprocesses actually takes noticeable amounts of time, but there isn't really any aternative unless we swap out the dataframe for something less flexible.

Could also be a setting in lyse itself rather than the scripts, so you can change it for multiple scripts at once. Do multishot analysis on: shots from today/shots from last n sequences.

What do you think, better?

issue.title: Multi-shot routines should be able to ask for a sub-set of the dataframe

content.raw: I would stick with the original idea because different scripts might want a different number of sequences (for instance one might be some sort of daily monitor, another might be the last n sequences, etc). It's thus probably easier to have this as an argument to the data() methods rather that having to modify a graphical object for each script. Also, we generally have the number of sequences to analyse dynamic, based on a global (see #6).
content.html: I would stick with the original idea because different scripts might want a different number of sequences (for instance one might be some sort of daily monitor, another might be the last n sequences, etc). It's thus probably easier to have this as an argument to the data() methods rather that having to modify a graphical object for each script. Also, we generally have the number of sequences to analyse dynamic, based on a global (see #6).
